I've added the following questions I find helpful when conducting FED interviews:

I believe currying is a really great concept to gauge a developer's knowledge of JavaScript and I've been asked about it a couple of times during interviews. I thought it would be a great addition for people studying. Great list of questions!

This question will only ever get a straw-man's argument at best. And this article Responsive vs Adaptive Design ‚Äì Which is Best for Mobile Viewing of Your Website? only strengthens the position that there is now real difference between the two when it comes to coding a solution. Sure, there may be a design strategy here, but this is not a list of questions for designers.
The replacement question gets to the core of the question about an actual implementation strategy for development.
The expected answer from the question would be the expectation that the interviewee would understand that there is a significant different between coding a UI from a desktop-first perspective versus a mobile-first one. Also, this person would expect to understand the difference between min-width versus max-width in these scenarios.

One question was removed as it is a duplicate question in relation to media queries.
The new question is added to inquire as to a person's knowledge of the two very different code styles when writing CSS.
Can you explain the differences between Functional CSS and Component CSS development styles? What are some advantages/disadvantages of either style?

An interviewer would expect answers to illustrate the differences between these coding styles and possible naming conventions. Advantages/disadvantages are opinions for the most part and would allow the interviewer to gain perspective as to the developer's personal insights on the subject.
